{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Use British English|date=March 2015}} {{primary sources|date=May 2008}} {{Infobox political party |country = the United Kingdom |name = Socialist People's Party |colorcode = {{Socialist People's Party (Furness)/meta/color}} |logo = [[File:Socialist People's Party logo.jpg|100px|"Socialist People's Party" logo]] |leader = Jim Hamezian |founded = 1995 |dissolved = 2015 |ideology = [[Socialism]] |position = [[Left-wing]] |colours = [[Red]] and [[Green]] with [[White]] |headquarters = 90 Schneider Road
Barrow-in-Furness
LA14 5DP }} The '''People's Party''' or '''Socialist People's Party''' was a minor [[political party]] in the [[Furness]] region of [[England]]. The party was founded in 1995 by four [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] borough councillors who had been suspended from Labour for opposing a reduction in the [[House|housing]] [[budget]]. It was initially known as the '''People's Labour Party''', and stood their chair, Jim Hamezeian, in the [[Barrow and Furness (UK Parliament constituency)|Barrow and Furness]] constituency in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]]. He received 1,995 votes, 4.1% of the total in the constituency. The party campaigned on a variety of local issues. A split led to two of its four councillors leaving and standing as [[independent (politician)|independents]] in the [[Barrow-in-Furness Council election, 2003|2003 local elections]]; the two People's Party councillors then lost their seats. However, in the [[Barrow-in-Furness Council election, 2006|2006 local elections]], party leader Jim Hamezian regained his seat in the [[Ormsgill]] ward. In the [[Barrow-in-Furness Council election, 2008|2008 local elections]], one councillor was elected in Central Ward and three others elected in Ormsgill. Following this, in elections to [[Cumbria County Council]] in 2009, Jim Hamezeian was elected to serve for Ormsgill ward in Barrow-in-Furness.{{cite web|url= http://www.cumbria.gov.uk/election2009/results/text/division.asp?division=Ormsgill&district=Barrow|title= Cumbria County Council website}} After that, the party's support dropped: in the [[Barrow-in-Furness Council election, 2010|2010 local elections]] the SPP lost two councillors, and lost all representation on the Borough council in [[Barrow-in-Furness Council election, 2011|2011 local elections]]. The SPP retained one councillor on [[Cumbria County Council]] until the [[United Kingdom local elections, 2013|May 2013 elections]], when they lost all representation. The party deregistered with the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] in 2015 and its website is no longer active. ==References== ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110109113243/http://www.socialistpeoplesparty.org/ Socialist People's Party] [[Category:Labour Party (UK) breakaway groups]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1995]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1995]] [[Category:Socialist parties in England]] [[Category:Furness]] [[Category:Defunct socialist parties in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Politics of Cumbria]]

'''Supreme Student Government (secondary)'''
{{lang|tl|Programa para sa Pamahalaan ng mga Mag-aaral}}{{lang|tl|Kataas-taasang Pamahalaan ng mga Mag-aaral}} |image = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = SGP/SPG/SSG{{ref|a|a}} |formation = 2003 ''(Supreme Student Government institutionalized)''
2014 ''(Supreme Pupil and Supreme Student Governments unified and institutionalized)'' |type = [[Students' union|Student Government]] (Supreme Pupil Government in elementary schools and Supreme Student Governments in secondary schools of the [[Philippines]]) |headquarters = DepEd Complex, Meralco Avenue, [[Pasig City]] |location = {{flag|Philippines}} |region_served = All [[Regions of the Philippines|regions]], except [[Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao|ARMM]] |membership = all enrolled elementary and secondary students in regions stated above{{ref|b|b}} |language = English, Filipino |leader_title = |leader_name = |key_people = Joey G. Pelaez, former DepEd-Center for Students and Co-curricular Affairs Executive Director
Rizalino D. Rivera, DepEd Undersecretary for Regional Operations |main_organ = |parent_organization = [[Department of Education (Philippines)|Department of Education]] - Office of the Undersecretary for Regional Operations |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = |remarks = |former name = }} The '''Student Government Program''' (SGP) is the Philippines' program for pupil governments in elementary schools student governments in secondary schools of the [[Department of Education (Philippines)|Department of Education]], under the Office of the Undersecretary for Regional Operations. It is the foremost co-curricular student organization authorized to implement pertinent programs, projects, and activities in Philippine schools as mandated by the Department of Education. The Philippines has a complex student union with different names such as ''student government'', the term used in all public secondary schools and some of the universities and/or colleges and ''student council'' for most of the colleges/universities. ==History== The Center for Students and Co-Curricular Affairs (CSCA) was established in 1996 in order to further facilitate co-curricular work of student councils in the country and mold them to be better leaders. In 2003, the Supreme Student Governments were institutionalized starting with the establishment of the National Federation of Supreme Student Governments (NFSSG) with David Maulas of Bohol as its first National Federation President elected during the 1st National Leadership Training for Student Government Officers (NLTSGO). An institutionalized Constitution and By Laws of the Supreme Student Governments were enforced through a Department Order No. 43, s. 2005, then revised in 2009 as per Department Order No. 79, s. 2009. The last set of National Federation officers were elected September 2012 with Raja Barber of Oriental Mindoro as the last National Federation President. In 2014, through Department Order No. 47, s. 2014 the Constitution and By-Laws of Supreme Pupil Governments in elementary schools and Supreme Student Governments in secondary schools around the country were unified. This marks the year where the Supreme Pupil Governments are institutionalized. Currently the program is now under the Office of the Undersecretary for Regional Operations. ==Notes== {{ref|a|a}} SGP - Student Government Program; SPG - Supreme Pupil Government; SSG - Supreme Student Government
{{ref|b|b}} All ''bona fide'' students enrolled are considered as members of the SPG/SSG as stated in Article IV, Section 1 of the Constitution and By-Laws of the Supreme Pupil Government and Supreme Student Government in Elementary and Secondary Schools. ==References== * {{cite web | title=Standard Constitution of the Supreme Student Governments in Secondary Schools | work= | url=http://www.deped.gov.ph/orders/do-47-s-2014 | accessdate=2015-12-31}} * {{cite web | title=Revised Constitution of the Supreme Student Governments in Secondary Schools | work= | url=http://www.deped.gov.ph/orders/do-79-s-2009 | accessdate=2015-12-31}} * {{cite web | title=Constitution and By-Laws of the Supreme Pupil Government and Supreme Student Government in Elementary and Secondary Schools | work= | url=http://www.deped.gov.ph/orders/do-47-s-2014 | accessdate=2015-12-31}} [[Category:Groups of students' unions]] [[Category:Higher education in the Philippines]] [[Category:Student government]]

revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = https://www.facebook.com/Syrian.Revolution/ | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} The '''Syrian Revolution Network''' ({{lang-ar|شبكة الثورة السورية}}), originally called the '''Syrian Revolution 2011''' and the '''Syrian Days of Rage''', is a [[Syrian opposition]] [[activist organization]] active in the [[Syrian Civil War]]. It was originally a [[Facebook page]] created by [[Fida al-Sayed]], a [[Sweden|Swedish]] activist living in [[Eskilstuna]], during the [[Arab Spring]] in the beginning of 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/10/world/middleeast/10syria.html?mcubz=3|title=Syria Restores Access to Facebook and YouTube|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Jennifer Preston|date=9 February 2011}} By May 2011, it was considered the most influential Syrian activist organization in the mobilization of protesters against the [[Syrian government]] during the [[civil uprising phase of the Syrian Civil War|Syrian uprising]]. ==History== ===Creation=== In January 2011, during the [[Arab Spring]] and the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|Egyptian Revolution]], [[Fida al-Sayed]], together with his two younger brothers Mustafa and Yasir, created the page '''"Syrian Revolution"''' on [[Facebook]].{{cite news|title=Om oroligheterna i Syrien |url=http://svtplay.se/v/2493118/gomorron_sverige/om_oroligheterna_i_syrien |publisher=[[Sveriges Television|SVT]] |date=2 August 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326175244/http://svtplay.se/v/2493118/gomorron_sverige/om_oroligheterna_i_syrien |archivedate=26 March 2012 |df= }} By February, the page gained more than 16,000 followers. It began to call for a "day of rage" in Syria against the government of [[Bashar al-Assad]], but was initially not able to mobilize protests in Syria. In an interview on [[Nyhetsmorgon]] at [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]], Fida explained that when he started the page before the "revolution," people laughed at him and said that there will never be an uprising in Syria, while others supported the initiative. He pointed several times that it is a peaceful movement for [[freedom]] and [[democracy]]. He said that they did not have to do any marketing for the page, as the situation in Syria was marketing itself. He said he no longer administrated the page alone, he only founded it, and he now has the help of hundreds of [[Syrians|young people in Syria]].{{cite news |title=Nyhetsmorgon - Så påverkar revolutionen i Libyen upproret i Syrien |url=http://www.tv4play.se/nyheter_och_debatt/nyhetsmorgon?title=sa_paverkar_revolutionen_i_libyen_upproret_i_syrien&videoid=1946736 |publisher=[[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]] |date=24 August 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}} ===Beginning of the Syrian uprising=== {{see|Civil uprising phase of the Syrian Civil War}} On 15 March 2011, around 200 protesters gathered in [[Damascus]] to demand reforms and the end to the [[state of emergency]] in Syria. The Syrian Revolution 2011 Facebook page, then with more than 41,000 followers, called for the protest.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/syria-revolution-revolt-against-bashar-al--assads-regime/2011/03/15/ABrwNEX_blog.html|title=Syria revolution: A revolt brews against Bashar al- Assad’s regime|work=[[The Washington Post]]|author=Elizabeth Flock|date=15 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-12749674|title=Mid-East unrest: Syrian protests in Damascus and Aleppo|work=[[BBC]]|date=15 March 2011}} On 18 March 2011, the Syrian Revolution 2011 Facebook page called for a "Day of Dignity" in Syria.{{cite news|last=Iddon|first=Paul|title=A recap of the Syrian crisis to date|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/329590|accessdate=20 September 2013|work=Digital Journal|date=30 July 2012}} After Islamic [[Jumu'ah|Friday prayers]], thousands of protesters gathered in 4 cities, notably in [[Siege of Daraa|Daraa]], and called for freedom and democracy and against [[corruption]]. Government forces violently suppressed all of the protests.{{cite news|title=In Syria, Crackdown After Protests|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/19/world/middleeast/19syria.html?_r=0|accessdate=28 February 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=18 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oC55uPBKYqU |title=Violence flares at Syrian protest |publisher=Youtube/Al Jazeera (video)|date=18 March 2011|accessdate=28 January 2014| deadurl= no}} In April 2011, the Syrian Revolution 2011 Facebook page had more than 120,000 followers. It once again called for Syrians to take to the streets for Friday protests in Syria.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-13168276|title=Syria's spontaneously organised protests|work=BBC|author=Kim Ghattas|date=22 April 2011}} By May, the Facebook page, which had more than 180,000 followers,{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/23/world/middleeast/23facebook.html?mcubz=3|title=Seeking to Disrupt Protesters, Syria Cracks Down on Social Media|work=The New York Times|author=Jennifer Preston|date=22 May 2011}} transformed into a wider network with more than 250,000 members in more than 8 [[social media]] sites. The Syrian Revolution Network became the most influential Syrian opposition organization, influencing and mobilizing thousands of protesters against the Syrian government. In July 2011, [[BBC Arabic]] showed in a special report how Fida run the page from his apartment in [[Eskilstuna]]. Fida explained that 75% of the administrators who ran the site were from within Syria. Fida also told that it is a difficult process before a video is approved and posted on the site: the event must have been filmed and sent by various independent sources, even sometimes needed to be confirmed by filming the date on a local newspaper, or that some of the protesters show big signs where you can clearly see the week's campaign name.{{cite news |title=حصريا : أحمد الشيخ في غرفة عمليات الثورة السورية |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6kqiY0u53M4&feature=related |publisher=[[BBC Arabic]] |date=6 July 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}} ===Escalation and civil war=== One of the key media activists affiliated with the Syrian Revolution Network is Moaz al-Shami. Moaz al-Shami was from [[Damascus]],{{cite web|url=http://eldorar.com/node/108527|title=Supporters of the Sham Liberation Organization are raising a banner in a controversial demonstration|work=Al-Dorar al-Shamia|date=4 February 2017}} and during the first 3 years of the [[Syrian Civil War]], he mainly operated in and around Damascus. Battles of the war he covered in Damascus included the [[Rif Dimashq offensive (November 2012–February 2013)|Damascus offensive of November 2012]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/11/201211391048764834.html|title='Heavy fighting' at Syria's Taftanaz airbase|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=4 November 2012}} and the [[Damascus offensive (2013)|Damascus offensive of February 2013]],{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-syria-crisis-idUSBRE91I0GK20130220|title=Syria "Scud-type" missile said to kill 20 in Aleppo|work=[[Reuters]]|author=Khaled Yacoub Oweis|date=20 February 2013}} In March 2013, [[Reuters]] considered Moaz al-Shami to be one of the leading opposition activists in Damascus.{{Cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-syria-crisis-alkhatib-idUKBRE92N07A20130324|title=Syrian opposition leader Alkhatib resigns|work=Reuters|author=Omar Fahmy and Khaled Yacoub Oweis|date=24 March 2013}} Some time later in the war, Moaz al-Shami moved to the [[Idlib Governorate]] in northwestern Syria, where he currently operates. Since September 2015, he covered the [[Russian military intervention in Syria]], including the bombing of [[Aleppo]] and [[Idlib]] by the [[Russian Air Force]].{{cite web|url=http://www.almodon.com/media/2016/12/6/%D8%A5%D8%AF%D9%84%D8%A8-%D8%AC%D9%8A%D8%B4-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AD-%D9%8A%D8%B7%D9%84%D9%82-%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AD-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B4%D8%B7-%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%B0-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%8A|title=Idlib: "the army of conquest" free activist Moaz Shami|work=Al-Modon|date=6 December 2016}} On 7 March 2016, while he was covering [[Syrian protests (March–April 2016)|protests]] in rebel-held towns in Idlib, Moaz was arrested by [[al-Qaeda]]'s [[al-Nusra Front]], part of the [[Army of Conquest]].{{cite web|url=http://www.zaitonmag.com/?p=8841|title=Front of victory dispersed a demonstration against the regime and arrest activists in the countryside Idlib|work=Zaiton Mag|date=7 March 2017}} On 5 December 2016, he was once again arrested by the Army of Conquest after disputes with an Army of Conquest [[Sharia]] judge in Idlib, but was soon released after. In the beginning of 2017, Moaz al-Shami covered the rise of [[Tahrir al-Sham]] in Idlib. On 4 April 2017, he recorded photographs and videos of the [[Khan Shaykhun chemical attack]] and its aftermath.{{cite web|url=http://noticias.band.uol.com.br/mundo/noticia/100000853043/jornalista-sirio-que-cobriu-ataque-quimico-faz-apelo.html|title=Syrian journalist who covered chemical attack in the country hopes that images touch the world|work=Band.com.br|date=8 April 2017}} ==See also== * [[Local Coordination Committees of Syria]] * [[Syrian Revolution Coordinators Union]] * [[Syrian Revolution General Commission]] * [[Supreme Council of the Syrian Revolution]] ==External links== * [https://www.facebook.com/Syrian.Revolution/ Syrian Revolution Network] on [[Facebook]] * [https://twitter.com/RevolutionSyria Syrian Revolution Network] on [[Twitter]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Syrian Civil War}} [[Category:Political opposition organizations]] [[Category:Syrian democracy movements]] [[Category:Syrian opposition]] [[Category:Organizations of the Arab Spring]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2011]] [[Category:Protests in Syria]] [[Category:Organizations of the Syrian Civil War]]

{{Underlinked|date=February 2014}}
'''Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures''' ('''TTPs''') is an essential concept in [[terrorism]] and [[cyber security]] studies.<ref name=Sullivan2008/>
The role of TTPs in terrorism analysis is to identify individual [[behavioral pattern|patterns of behavior]] of a particular terrorist activity, or a particular terrorist organisation, and to examine and categorize more general tactics and weapons used by a particular terrorist activity, or a particular terrorist organisation.
== Requirement to identify individual terrorism TTPs == The current approach to terrorism analysis involves an examination of individual terrorist, or terrorist organisations use of particular weapons, used in specific ways, and different tactics and strategies being exhibited.<ref name=Sullivan2008/> Broadly, a wide range of TTPs have been exhibited historically by individual terrorist, or terrorist organisations worldwide.<ref>Flaherty, C. (2012) Dangerous Minds: Attps://eccp.poste.dككك Monograph on the Relationship Between Beliefs –Behaviours – Tactics. Published by OODA LOOP (7 September 2012).URL: http://www.oodaloop.com/security/2012/09/07/dangerous-minds-the-relationship-between-beliefs-behaviors-and-tactics/</ref>
== Key concepts ==
=== Evolution of TTPs === All terrorists, or terrorist organisations, worldwide historically have exhibited an evolution in TTPs. This can be as a result of: * changing circumstances; * resource availability; or, * changing ideologies, or 'war-focus'. In the case of the [[Taliban]], their tactics have consisted primarily of guerrilla-style [[improvised explosive device]] (IED) attacks and small-arms ambushes against international and state-level security forces and interests, such as police checkpoints and military supply convoys. However, more recently Taliban TTPs have expanded to include mass casualty attacks by [[ suicide bombers ]] and other suicide attacks in order to undermine the current government.
=== Kill-chain model === [[File:Flaherty Model of Terrorism Analysis Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures Kill Chain Model.jpg|thumb|right|The kill-chain model, and kill-chain model variations]] The [[kill chain|kill-chain]] model (KCM) is a conceptual tool used in terrorism analysis and studies.<ref name=Sullivan2008> Sullivan, J.P., Bauer, A. eds (2008). [http://file.lacounty.gov/lasd/cms1_144939.pdf Terrorism Early Warning: 10 Years of Achievement in Fighting Terrorism and Crime]. Los Angeles, CA: Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department.</ref> All terrorists' or terrorist organisations' TTPs form part of understanding the terrorist kill chain, which is the pattern of transactional activities, link together in order for a terrorist act to take place. Broadly, this involves describing the 'hierarchy of tasks and sub-tasks that may be involved in the execution', or in making a terrorist act happen.<ref name=Sullivan2008/> These can include the arrangement and sequence of activities a terrorist or terrorist organisation uses in planning, organizing, mobilizing, training, equipping and staging resources and operatives. These activities make up the terrorist or terrorist organisations' modus operandi or 'attack system'.<ref name=Sullivan2008/> Four sets of steps make-up the full KCM: * The first set of activities are the 'attack preparation steps'. In terms of terrorism analysis, individual transactions, such as acquiring finances, acquiring expertise, acquiring materiel, munitions or capability, recruiting members, conducting [[reconnaissance]], mission rehearsal, conducting an attack, have signatures that identify them as terrorist or criminal acts or are consistent with the operations of a specific individual, cell or group. * The second set of activities are called the 'execution timeline'. This identifies the timeline, along which the terrorist, or terrorist organisations various activities, leading up to an attack process flows time-wise. * The third set of activities is identified as 'targeting'. An individual or group would carry out some form of dedicated reconnaissance with the aim of identifying weaknesses in the site or operation; and with that information determine the best method of attack. * The fourth set of activities is identified as the 'planning stages'. These involve some type of planning activity embedded into the ‘kill chain’, and is part of the process of organizing, mobilizing, training, equipping, staging, collecting resources and operatives. These make up the terrorist or terrorist organisations’ [[modus operandi]], or its system of attack.
The KCM “sequence of activities”<ref name=Sullivan2008/> is not linear, but discontinuous. Three additional KCM scenarios can be identified:<ref>Flaherty, C. (2012) Dangerous Minds: A Monograph on the Relationship Between Beliefs –Behaviours – Tactics. Published by OODA LOOP (7 September 2012).URL: http://www.oodaloop.com/security/2012/09/07/dangerous-minds-the-relationship-between-beliefs-behaviors-and-tactics/</ref> * An individual or group actively promote a terrorist/extremist ideology on the internet, in books, pamphlets, etc. This is then picked up by another terrorist, or terrorist organisations, who then act on this. * Two or more parallel kill chain sequence of activities (by various individuals/groups) which are only indirectly connected by intermediary individuals/groups. Sharing similar beliefs, but as well cross over into complementary beliefs/ideologies. Many such intermediaries can operate in this space, passing ideas and resources, even recruits between the various terrorist, or terrorist organisations, groups and cells. * A terrorist or terrorist organisations picks up ideas, knowledge, etc., and jump-start into various places along the ‘standard’ concept of the KCM.
== Transfer of Terrorist Tactics, Techniques and Procedures == Terrorist TTPs are often transferred between various terrorists, or terrorist organisations, and they often learn from each other.<ref>Hedges, M. Karasik, T. Evolving Terrorist Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTP) Migration Across South Asia, Caucasus, and the Middle East. INEGMA Special Report No. 7. URL: {{cite web |url=http://terror-mirror.com/books/etrrep014.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904024306/http://terror-mirror.com/books/etrrep014.pdf |archivedate=2012-09-04 |df= }}</ref> The degree to which the transfer of TTPs occurs depends on their relative success when transferred to a different conflict, and a different environment. The similarities in TTPs between various terrorists, or terrorist organisations, across conflicts and periods suggest a transfer of information. * [[Explicit knowledge|Explicit Knowledge]]: This is the [[ theory | theoretical ]] information which is often stored in hard copies, such as textbooks, manuals and on computers through [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] and video files. These are extremely easy to get hold of, but without the appropriate teaching or experience, this easy access information is commonly not effectively used. * Tactical Knowledge: Most commonly taught or learnt through experience and hands on teaching. This requires training establishments to be organised. For terrorists, or terrorist organisations, acquiring this information is harder, and more difficult; however, it is seen as a more effective transfer of knowledge.
== Key tactical concepts related to TTPs == Several key tactical concepts can be related to TTPs, which are typically used in [[terrorism]] or [[insurgency]] operations. * [[Interposing tactics]]<ref>Flaherty, C. (2009) Interposing Tactics. Red Team Journal.com URL: http://redteamjournal.com/2009/12/interposing-tactics/</ref> * [[Mimicking operations]]<ref>Flaherty, C.J. (December 2003) Mimicking Operations, Australian Army Journal. (1)2: 11-14. URL: http://www.army.gov.au/Our-future/LWSC/Our-publications/Australian-Army-Journal/Past-issues/~/media/Files/Our%20future/LWSC%20Publications/AAJ/2003Summer/02-InformationWarfareAndMi.pdf</ref> * [[Rhizome Manoeuvre]]<ref>Flaherty, C. (2012) Dangerous Minds: A Monograph on the Relationship Between Beliefs –Behaviours – Tactics. Published by OODA LOOP (7 September 2012).URL: http://www.oodaloop.com/security/2012/09/07/dangerous-minds-the-relationship-between-beliefs-behaviors-and-tactics/</ref> * [[Three-Dimensional (3D) Tactics Analysis|Three-dimensional (3D) tactics analysis]] * [[Swarming (military)|Swarming tactics]] * [[Dynamic defence|Deliberate erratic actions, and erratic attacks]]<ref>Flaherty, C. (2009) 2D Verses 3D Tactical Supremacy in Urban Operations. Journal of Information Warfare. (8)2: 13-24.</ref> * [[Dynamic defence]]<ref>Flaherty, C. (2009) 2D Verses 3D Tactical Supremacy in Urban Operations. Journal of Information Warfare. (8)2: 13-24.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

page.title: The rich get richer and the poor get poorer

revision.text:
{{About|the catchphrase|the theoretical process|wealth concentration|a full discussion of the social, economic, and political phenomena to which the phrase refers|economic inequality}}
'''"The rich get richer and the poor get poorer"''' is an [[aphorism]] due to [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]]. In ''[[A Defence of Poetry]] (''1821, not published until 1840) Shelley remarked that [[Utilitarianism|the promoters of utility]] had
: exemplified the saying, “To him that hath, more shall be given; and from him that hath not, the little that he hath shall be taken away.” The rich have become richer, and the poor have become poorer; and the vessel of the State is driven [[Between Scylla and Charybdis|between the Scylla and Charybdis]] of anarchy and despotism.<ref>{{cite book|title=A Defence of Poetry (from the Harvard Classics: English Essays: Sidney to Macaulay|last=Shelley|first=Percy Bysshe|publisher=Bartleby.com|year=1909–14}}</ref>
"To him that hath" ''etc''. is a reference to Matthew 25:29 (the [[Parable of the talents or minas|parable of the talents]], see also [[Matthew effect]]). The aphorism is commonly evoked, with variations in wording, as a synopsis of the effect of [[free market]] [[capitalism]] producing [[Economic inequality|inequality]].
==Predecessors== [[Andrew Jackson]], the seventh President of the U.S. (1829–1837), in his 1832 [[Second Bank of the United States|bank veto]], said that : when the laws undertake... to make the rich richer and the potent more powerful, the humble members of society... have a right to complain of the injustice to their Government.<ref>{{cite book|title=Andrew Jackson V. Henry Clay: Democracy and Development in Antebellum America|last=Watson|first=Harry L.|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|year=1998|isbn=0-312-17772-0}} [https://www.amazon.com/gp/reader/0312177720/?keywords=%22rich+richer%22&v=search-inside]</ref><ref>{{gutenberg|no=10858 |name=A Compilation of the Messages and Papers of the Presidents, Vol. 2, Part 3, Andrew Jackson, 1st term}}</ref>
The phrase also resembles two [[Bible]] verses from the [[Gospel of Matthew]]: : For whosoever hath, to him shall be given, and he shall have more abundance: but whosoever hath not, from him shall be taken away even that he hath.<ref>{{Bibleverse|Matthew|13:12|KJV}}</ref> : For unto every one that hath shall be given, and he shall have abundance: but from him that hath not shall be taken away even that which he hath.<ref>{{Bibleverse|Matthew|25:29|KJV}}</ref>
=="Ain't We Got Fun"== The phrase was popularized in 1921 in the wildly successful song "[[Ain't We Got Fun]]?", and the phrase is sometimes attributed to the song's lyricists, [[Gus Kahn]] and [[Raymond B. Egan]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://everything2.net/index.pl?node_id=1101156 |title = Ain't We Got Fun |accessdate = 2006-08-11 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.geocities.com/dferg5493/aintwegotfun.htm |title = Ain't We Got Fun |publisher = Don Ferguson |accessdate = 2006-08-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20041210204617/http://www.geocities.com/dferg5493/aintwegotfun.htm |archivedate = 2004-12-10 }}</ref> The line is sometimes mistakenly attributed to [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]]. It appears in ''[[The Great Gatsby]]'', as : the rich get richer and the poor get—children! The character Gatsby orders the character Klipspringer, sitting at the piano, "Don't talk so much, old sport... Play!" and Klipspringer breaks into the Whiting, Kahn and Egan song.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Great Gatsby|last=Fitzgerald|first=F. Scott|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1998|isbn=0-19-283269-7|origyear=1921}} [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0192832697&id=ZMQv026FgT8C&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76&sig=TXJ-bqB-iGfrDrPn5AaxBl7Z7fc p. 76]; also at Project Gutenberg of Australia [http://gutenberg.net.au/ebooks02/0200041.txt]</ref>
==In economics== [[Thomas Piketty]]'s book ''[[Capital in the Twenty-First Century]]'' (2014) presents a body of empirical data spanning several hundred years that supports his central thesis that the owners of capital accumulate wealth more quickly than those who provide labour, a phenomenon widely described with the term "the rich-get-richer".<ref>https://newrepublic.com/article/117429/capital-twenty-first-century-thomas-piketty-reviewed</ref>
== In modern politics == In the United States, the phrase has been used frequently to describe socioeconomic trends under the [[Ronald Reagan]] and [[George H. W. Bush]] presidencies,<ref>[[James K. Galbraith]]. "[http://archive.salon.com/opinion/feature/2004/06/08/reaganomics/index_np.html The rich got richer] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929143539/http://archive.salon.com/opinion/feature/2004/06/08/reaganomics/index_np.html |date=2007-09-29 }}." ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'', June 8, 2004</ref><ref>Edward N. Wolf. "[http://www.epinet.org/content.cfm/paycheck_wages_summary_wages The rich get increasingly richer: Latest data on household wealth during the 1980s] {{Webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20041023043625/http://www.epinet.org/content.cfm/paycheck_wages_summary_wages |date=2004-10-23 }}." [[Economic Policy Institute]] Briefing Paper #36. 1993.</ref><ref>[[Alan Reynolds (economist)|Alan Reynolds]]. "[http://www.nationalreview.com/reagan/reynolds200406101357.asp Upstarts and Downstarts] (The Real Reagan Record)." ''National Review'', August 31, 1992.</ref> and in the [[United Kingdom]] to refer to the [[Premiership of Margaret Thatcher|Thatcher era]].<ref>{{cite news |last1 = Nunns |first1 = Alex |title = Dispelling the Thatcher myths |url = http://www.redpepper.org.uk/dispelling-the-thatcher-myths/ |accessdate = 2 May 2016 |work = Red Pepper |date = April 2013 |quote = It's said that Thatcher made the British people richer. She didn't. ... The rich got richer; the poor got poorer. }}</ref> Thatcher famously retorted to a question posed by the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Lib Dem]] MP [[Simon Hughes]] about [[Economic inequality|wealth inequality]] in the United Kingdom by saying "he would rather that the poor were poorer, provided that the rich were less rich. ... What a policy. Yes, he would rather have the poor poorer, provided that the rich were less rich. That is the Liberal policy."<ref>{{cite news |title = HC S: [Confidence in Her Majesty's Government] |url = http://www.margaretthatcher.org/document/108256 |accessdate = 2 May 2016 |work = House of Commons Speech |issue = 22 November 1990 |publisher = [[Hansard]] HC [181/445-53] |via = Margaret Thatcher Foundation |date = 22 November 1990 |quote = People on all levels of income are better off than they were in 1979. The hon. Gentleman is saying that he would rather that the poor were poorer, provided that the rich were less rich. That way one will never create the wealth for better social services, as we have. What a policy. Yes, he would rather have the poor poorer, provided that the rich were less rich. That is the Liberal policy. }}</ref> It has also been used in the UK to refer to [[Cameron–Clegg coalition|the 2010–2015 coalition]] and [[Second Cameron ministry|2015–2016]] governments led by [[David Cameron]].<ref>Coalition:
*{{cite news |title = Tories Make the Rich Richer and the Poor Poorer |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/kamran-hussain/david-cameron-austerity_b_4310611.html |work = The Huffington Post UK |language = en-GB }} *{{cite news |last1 = Waugh |first1 = Rob |title = Rich have become richer thanks to 'austerity' politics - but poor lose out |url = http://metro.co.uk/2014/11/16/rich-have-become-richer-thanks-to-austerity-politics-but-poor-lose-out-4950177/ |accessdate = 2 May 2016 |work = Metro |date = 16 November 2014 }} 2015–present:
*{{cite news |title = Labour: soaring levels of homelessness under Cameron mean more children facing Christmas on streets |url = http://www.heraldscotland.com/politics/14160723.Labour__soaring_levels_of_homelessness_under_Cameron_mean_more_children_facing_Christmas_on_streets/ |accessdate = 2 May 2016 |work = Herald Scotland }} *{{cite news |title = Cameron tries to soothe MPs ahead of challenging year for party management |url = http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2016/01/cameron-tries-to-soothe-mps-ahead-of-difficult-year-for-party-management/ |accessdate = 2 May 2016 |work = Coffee House |date = 2 January 2016 |language = en-US }}</ref>
==Other uses== In [[statistics]], the phrase "the rich get richer" is often used as an informal description of the behavior of [[Chinese restaurant process]]es and other [[preferential attachment]] processes, where the probability of the next outcome in a series taking on a particular value is proportional to the number of outcomes already having that particular value. This is useful for modeling many real-world processes that are akin to "popularity contests", where the popularity of a particular choice causes new participants to adopt the same choice (which can lead to the outsized influence of the first few participants).
===Markets with social influence=== Product recommendations and information about past purchases have been shown to influence consumers choices significantly whether it is for music, movie, book, technological, and other type of products. Social influence often induces a rich-get-richer phenomenon ([[Matthew effect]]) where popular products tend to become even more popular.<ref name="altszyler2017">{{cite journal | url= http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0180040 | title= Transient dynamics in trial-offer markets with social influence: Trade-offs between appeal and quality. |author1= Altszyler, E |author2=Berbeglia, F.| author3= Berbeglia, G. |author4=Van Hentenryck, P. | journal= PLoS ONE | year=2017 |volume=12|issue=7 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0180040 | page=e0180040|bibcode=2017PLoSO..1280040A }}</ref>

{{primary|date=June 2018}} {{notability|date=June 2018}} {{refimprove|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox political party | name = Western Independence Party of Saskatchewan | native_name = | _subheader = Active provincial party | logo = | leader = Neil Fenske<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/neil.fenske.79]</ref> | president = | chairman = | chairperson = | spokesperson = | leader1_title = | leader1_name = | foundation = {{Start date|2003}} | dissolution = | merger = | split = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | headquarters = | ideology = Saskatchewan independence, [[Libertarianism]] | position = | national = | international = | student_wing = | youth_wing = | membership = | membership_year = | colours = | colors = | colorcode = #074FA2 | blank1_title = Fiscal policy | blank1 = | blank2_title = Social policy | blank2 = | seats1_title = Seats in the House of Commons | seats1 = | seats2_title = Seats in the Senate | seats2 = | seats3_title = Seats in [[Legislative Assembly of Saskatchewan|Legislature]] | seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|61|hex=#074FA2}} | website = {{URL|https://www.facebook.com/pg/Western-Independence-Party-of-Saskatchewan-810249165794566}} | country = Canada | state = Saskatchewan | parties_dab1 = List of political parties in Saskatchewan | elections_dab1= List of Saskatchewan general elections | footnotes = }} The '''Western Independence Party of Saskatchewan''' is a registered provincial [[political party]] in [[Saskatchewan]], Canada. It advocates for the independence of Saskatchewan, and libertarian ideals. It is not affiliated with any federal party. It supports [[Fiscal conservatism|fiscally conservative]] and socially moderate policies.
==History== The party was formed on July 12, 2003, and nominated 17 candidates in the November 5, [[Saskatchewan general election, 2003|2003 provincial election]]. These candidates won a total of 2,735 votes, or 0.64% of the provincial total.
The past party president is Frank Serfas, and the past deputy leader is [[David Sawkiw]]. The party nominated eight candidates for the [[Saskatchewan general election, 2007|2007 election]], two in the [[Saskatchewan general election, 2011|2011 election]], and four in the [[Saskatchewan general election, 2016|2016 election]].
At 2018, the party's current [[Party leader|leader]] is Neil Fenske.<ref>https://www.facebook.com/neil.fenske.79</ref>
Besides the party's support for independence, the party's platform is [[secularism|secular]] and [[libertarianism|libertarian]] in nature, a distinguishing feature from some of the other separatist parties in [[Western Canada]]. The WIP of Saskatchewan has no ties with the [[Separation Party of Alberta]], the [[Western Canada Party]], or the [[Alberta Independence Party]].
The party not affiliated to the [[Western Canada Concept Party of British Columbia]] or the [[British Columbia]]-based [[Western Block Party]] and has made considerable effort to distance itself from [[Doug Christie (lawyer)|Doug Christie]], the leader of those parties. Whereas Christie has been mired in controversy for defending [[Holocaust denial|Holocaust deniers]] and has been accused of being an [[anti-Semitism|anti-Semite]], the WIP has made an explicit statement in support of the [[Israel|State of Israel]].
==About== The Western Independence Party of Saskatchewan is a registered political party in the province of Saskatchewan, with a focus on three principles:<ref>https://www.facebook.com/pg/Western-Independence-Party-of-Saskatchewan-810249165794566/about/</ref>
:*Decentralize political power from the Premier's Office to the people. :*Rebalance economic power from monopolistic Corporations to the producers of wealth. :*Give policy back to the MLA's that have earned the trust of their people instead of the smoke filled back rooms of the political parties.
